page.title: Timeline of the 2011 Egyptian revolution under Supreme Council of the Armed Forces

rev.diff:
Line 138: Line 138:
On the 4 July, an explosion at the [[Arab Gas Pipeline|pipeline]] near [[Nagah]] in the [[Sinai Peninsula]] halted natural gas supplies to Israel and Jordan. This was the third attack on Egyptian gas pipelines since Mubarak was removed from power.<ref name=aljazeera040711/> There was also a failed attempt to attack the pipeline in March.<ref name=aljazeera040711>{{cite news | agency=[[Al Jazeera]]| url= http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/07/2011740176861868.html | title = Blast hits Egyptian gas pipeline | date = 4 July 2011 | accessdate=4 July 2011}}</ref>
On the 4 July, an explosion at the [[Arab Gas Pipeline|pipeline]] near [[Nagah]] in the [[Sinai Peninsula]] halted natural gas supplies to Israel and Jordan. This was the third attack on Egyptian gas pipelines since Mubarak was removed from power.<ref name=aljazeera040711/> There was also a failed attempt to attack the pipeline in March.<ref name=aljazeera040711>{{cite news | agency=[[Al Jazeera]]| url= http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/07/2011740176861868.html | title = Blast hits Egyptian gas pipeline | date = 4 July 2011 | accessdate=4 July 2011}}</ref>
â
On the 8 July, hundreds of thousands of protesters gathered for what they called the "Friday of Determination"<ref name="englishahram" /> or the "March of the Million" in Suez, Alexandria, Cairo and other cities. They demanded immediate reforms and swifter [[Trials and judicial hearings following the 2011 Egyptian revolution|prosecution of former officials]] from the ousted government.
+
On the 8 July, hundreds of thousands of protesters gathered for what they called the "Friday of Determination"<ref name="englishahram" /> or the "March of the Million" in Suez, Alexandria, Cairo and other cities. They demanded immediate reforms and swifter [[Trials and judicial hearings following the 2011 Egyptian revolution|prosecution of former officials]] from the ousted government. Also on July 8th, revolutionaries in Tahrir square have begun another sit-in which stands to this day.
Most of Egypt's political parties and coalitions, including the [[Muslim Brotherhood]], supported widespread calls for the protest to be staged across Egypt.<ref name="aljazeera1">{{cite web|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/video/middleeast/2011/07/20117810134178303.html |title=New protests rage across Egypt â Middle East |publisher=Al Jazeera English |accessdate=10 July 2011}}</ref> The protesters hoped to have a "second revolution".<ref name="aljazeera1"/> The main demand of these groups is to combine efforts toward achieving the goals of the revolution, including: [[Human rights in Egypt under the Supreme Council of the Armed Forces|banning the trial of civilians by military courts]]; setting a minimum wage; bringing Mubarak, his sons and the senior officials to justice quickly; banning former National Democratic Party (NDP) members from political activity for five years; releasing all political prisoners; purging the police, the legal system, the media, the universities and the banks of members of the former regime; electing new municipal councils, stopping the exportation of natural gas to Israel,<ref name="memri1"/> the arrest and trial of those responsible for killing protesters and restructuring the ministry of interior. An employee of [[Suez Canal University]] said that in [[Ismailiya]] there were also protests for higher wages and stable employment contracts.<ref name="englishahram"/> Protesters also called for the removal of [[Mohamed Hussein Tantawi]] who was said to be emblematic of the old regime.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/video/middleeast/2011/07/20117810134178303.html |title=New protests rage across Egypt â Middle East |publisher=Al Jazeera English |accessdate=10 July 2011}}</ref>
Most of Egypt's political parties and coalitions, including the [[Muslim Brotherhood]], supported widespread calls for the protest to be staged across Egypt.<ref name="aljazeera1">{{cite web|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/video/middleeast/2011/07/20117810134178303.html |title=New protests rage across Egypt â Middle East |publisher=Al Jazeera English |accessdate=10 July 2011}}</ref> The protesters hoped to have a "second revolution".<ref name="aljazeera1"/> The main demand of these groups is to combine efforts toward achieving the goals of the revolution, including: [[Human rights in Egypt under the Supreme Council of the Armed Forces|banning the trial of civilians by military courts]]; setting a minimum wage; bringing Mubarak, his sons and the senior officials to justice quickly; banning former National Democratic Party (NDP) members from political activity for five years; releasing all political prisoners; purging the police, the legal system, the media, the universities and the banks of members of the former regime; electing new municipal councils, stopping the exportation of natural gas to Israel,<ref name="memri1"/> the arrest and trial of those responsible for killing protesters and restructuring the ministry of interior. An employee of [[Suez Canal University]] said that in [[Ismailiya]] there were also protests for higher wages and stable employment contracts.<ref name="englishahram"/> Protesters also called for the removal of [[Mohamed Hussein Tantawi]] who was said to be emblematic of the old regime.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/video/middleeast/2011/07/20117810134178303.html |title=New protests rage across Egypt â Middle East |publisher=Al Jazeera English |accessdate=10 July 2011}}</ref>
